TRAINER TOOLS 
 
PROGRAMMING & TRAINER TOOLS
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
Nic Gill - Performance Advisory Panel (part one)
 
 
 
 
You are required to watch this video in full before completing the topic.
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
Nic Gill - Performance Advisory Panel (part two)
 
 
 
 
You are required to watch this video in full before completing the topic.
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
Nic Gill - Performance Advisory Panel (part three)
 
 
 
 
You are required to watch this video in full before completing the topic.
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
LIFTING GUIDE.
 
 
 
Please see the attached Fitstop Lifting Guide below. The Fitness team have built this along side the Fitness advisory panel in the aim to help assist members towards their working potential when lifting. The Guide is based off the Brzycki Formula which is built around 1RM into %. 
It should be noted that as a trainer, you can use this guide as a tool to open conversation up around what a member will be trying to lift on the day. As well as a tool to help prescribe members with weights to lifting on their working sets. 
EXAMPLE ONE: 
FORMAT: Tuesday LIFT, Deadlift focus session,  Heavy 5 reps. 
"Go find your last 3RM or what you think you can achieve for 3 reps for Deadlifts. If you can hit 
130kg
 for 3 reps you should be aiming for 
120kg 
for 5reps."
3RM: 130
5REP: 120
10REP: 100
EXAMPLE TWO: 
FORMAT: Friday LIFT, Front Squat session, working to 8 reps. 
"Look at the Lifting Guide and see what you've hit for 3 or 5 reps then work your way back to find a weight between the 5 rep and 10 rep weights. If you can hit 
75kg
 for 5 reps, you'll want to aim for between your 5 rep and 10 rep weight. I'd suggest working towards 
67.5-
70kg 
for 8 as a top set"
3RM: 80kg
5REP: 75kg
10REP: 65kg
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
LIFTING GUIDE IMPORTANT NOTES
 
 
 
Please note that the lifting guide is to be printed and put in location. (Members area or common area) 
  
- A3 Size
- High quality gloss paper
- Laminated 
 
 
 
 
Lifting Guide to download 
 
 
 
 
 
File Name
 
Size
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
853.1 kB
 
 
 
 
 
Fitstop Lifting Guide.png
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
REPS IN RESERVE. (RIR)
 
 
 
Reps in reserve is a trainer tool utilised to help members lift to the prescribed intention. The Fitness team use this as a method to measure the intensity of a lift by describing how many more reps a member could do before 
technical failure
. Technical failure is used to describe when a member can no longer perform a rep 
SAFELY with proper technique
. 
It's important to note that the reason we have moved away from % of 3RM and leant into RIR is for member experience and ease of session delivery. As we are all aware, we train the every day athlete (Fitstoppers). Expecting them to feel amazing and at their peak performance consistently is not achievable. RIR is a more effective way to communicate to a broad group of people at any level of fitness. This also allows a new member to understand the intention of the session without understanding what their 3RM. is. 
WHAT DOES RIR LOOK LIK EIN PROGRAMMING AND HOW DO I TALK ABOUT IT TO MEMBERS?
RIR will start to be included in our next 12 week block starting April 10th.
EXAMPLE
LIFT SESSION 9-18-8
S2&4) 
X8-6-
6-4-4
 
(RIR: 0-1) 
DEADLIFT
X15+ BANDED PULL APART 
(optional)
REST
TRAINER EXPLANATION. 
"During todays Deadlifts you'll be progressively adding more load on the bar as the reps go down, Your top sets should feel like you have 1 rep in reserve. Meaning when you finish the set you should feel like you only have 1 rep in reserve."
EXAMPLE
PERFORM SESSION 6 X 6
S2) ALT. EMOM
X5 FRONT SQUAT
 (RIR: 4) 
INTO MAX WALL BALLS  
TRAINER EXPLANATION.
"Today at station 2 we have an alternation EMOM with your partner. When you pick the weight for Front Squat you want to think of a weight you can still manage to complete about 4 more reps.  So we are not working to a maximum weight, think challenging but maintainable."
